ticket.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default
ticket.original-body:
My environment: Windows XP, Ruby 1.8.7, Rails 3.0.0.beta, Mongrel gem installed
When issueing the command @@@ rails server @@@ in my application path, WEBrick is started, instead of Mongrel. From looking in the documentation, there seems to be no option for setting the server. I tried with @@@ rails server mongrel @@@ , but that doesn't work too.
One workaround I've found, is to call @@@ rackup --server mongrel --port 3000 @@@ in your application path.
ticket.latest-body:

When issueing the command @@@ rails server @@@ in my application path, WEBrick is started, instead of Mongrel. From looking in the documentation, there seems to be no option for setting the server. I tried with @@@ rails server mongrel @@@ , but that doesn't work too.
One workaround I've found, is to call @@@ rackup --server mongrel --port 3000 @@@ in your application path.
ticket.original-body-html:
My environment: Windows XP, Ruby 1.8.7, Rails 3.0.0.beta, Mongrel gem installed

When issueing the command

rails server
in my application path, WEBrick is started, instead of Mongrel. From looking in the documentation, there seems to be no option for setting the server. I tried with 
rails server mongrel
, but that doesn't work too.

One workaround I've found, is to call

rackup --server mongrel --port 3000
in your application path.

version.body-html:
My environment: Windows XP, Ruby 1.8.7, Rails 3.0.0.beta, Mongrel gem installed

When issueing the command

rails server
in my application path, WEBrick is started, instead of Mongrel. From looking in the documentation, there seems to be no option for setting the server. I tried with 
rails server mongrel
, but that doesn't work too.

One workaround I've found, is to call

rackup --server mongrel --port 3000
in your application path.
version.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default

version.body: +1 Mongrel should be preferred over thin, and then webrick
version.body-html: +1 Mongrel should be preferred over thin, and then webrick
version.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default
"rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default

version.body:
The reason why `rails server` use Webrick over Mongrel was because the way gems area specify in the bundler. If you don't specify it in Gemfile, then `rails server`, or Rack more specifically, won't be able to use it.
So here, I'm proposing the patch for adding two commented lines suggesting them to put `gem 'mongel'` in case they want to use Mongrel.
@Kieran P
Right now, the order of server, or handler, is specify by Rack. I don't know how could I patch that. Please see http://github.com/rack/rack/blob/master/lib/rack/handler.rb#L36 for more information.
version.body-html:
The reason why rails server use Webrick over Mongrel was because the way gems area specify in the bundler. If you don't specify it in Gemfile, then rails server, or Rack more specifically, won't be able to use it.

So here, I'm proposing the patch for adding two commented lines suggesting them to put gem 'mongel' in case they want to use Mongrel.

@Kieran P

Right now, the order of server, or handler, is specify by Rack. I don't know how could I patch that. Please see http://github.com/rack/rack/blob/master/lib/rack/handler.rb#L36 for more information.
version.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default

version.body: It seems like I need to add `:group => :development` for that `Gemfile`. Another patch ...
version.body-html: It seems like I need to add :group => :development for that Gemfile. Another patch ...
version.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default

version.body:
While I'd prefer Mongrel to be used automatically, Prem's patch to add it (commented out) to the Gemfile seems to be a reasonable solution. The only way I can see to make it automatic would be something like this:
gem "mongrel", :group => :development rescue nil
But I don't know if that would work or make any sense.
version.body-html:
While I'd prefer Mongrel to be used automatically, Prem's patch to add it (commented out) to the Gemfile seems to be a reasonable solution. The only way I can see to make it automatic would be something like this:

gem "mongrel", :group => :development rescue nil

But I don't know if that would work or make any sense.
version.title: "rails server" doesn't start mongrel by default

version.body:
Craig Buchek
No, that won't do any good. If you specify that, Bundler would try to load/install the gem anyway.
However, this patch is stale now by this commit from DHH, so I'll mark it as resolved. Seems like if you want to use Mongrel, uncommenting it from Gemfile would be a way to go.
http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/834a45d8a2ae225b775c51d8ae266a4550e9fba1
version.body-html:
Craig Buchek

No, that won't do any good. If you specify that, Bundler would try to load/install the gem anyway.

However, this patch is stale now by this commit from DHH, so I'll mark it as resolved. Seems like if you want to use Mongrel, uncommenting it from Gemfile would be a way to go.

http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/834a45d8a2ae225b775c51d8ae266a...

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
